facts.text: Appellant was proprietor of firm Jawarmal Gulab Chand in Bombay.
Appellant advertised that people could invest capital in cotton, oil-seeds and other commodities and that J.G. Market reports issued by him could help them.
P.W. 2, Rajam, wholesale merchant dealing in cotton seed, ground nut cakes etc. at Kumbakonam, became a subscriber to the reports.

P.W. 2 asked appellant for business terms; appellant sent Ex. P-30 stating he undertook export, import, ready and forward business in various commodities in accordance with Pucca Adatia system and according to usual practice and usage of various associations concerned.
Neither appellant nor his firm was a member of any recognised association within the meaning of the Act.
P.W. 2 placed orders with appellant; correspondence and statements of accounts exchanged; P.W. 2 paid Rs. 12,000/- as margin between May 1, 1958 and June 15, 1958.
Appellant sent Rs. 1,000/- and final statement showing loss, claiming Rs. 398.52 due to appellant.

Prosecution case: Appellant induced P.W. 2 to send Rs. 12,000/- for forward contract business in cotton, castorseeds and ground nut by fraudulent representation that appellant conducted such business even though not actually entitled, thereby cheating P.W. 2.

Appellant's case: Could do business under Pucca Adatia system with members of recognised associations like Bombay Oil-Seed and Oil Exchange, East India Cotton Association, though not member himself; denied false representation or inducement.

Appellant charged under s. 420 IPC and s. 21(d) and (e) Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952; convicted by District Magistrate, Kumbakonam: RI one year, fine Rs. 1,000/- under IPC (Rs. 1,000/- to P.W. 2), fine Rs. 100/- under each clause of s. 21 Act.
Convictions and sentences affirmed by Sessions Judge, West Thanjavur on appeal.
Revision to Madras High Court dismissed on July 16, 1963 in Criminal Revision Case No. 1139 of 1961.
Appellant sent Ex. P-34 with copy of business terms Ex. P-34(a) representing he could do business in forward contracts in cotton, grains, seeds etc. per pucca adatia system and usage of associations.
Ex. P-33: Appellant sent telegram to P.W. 2 intimating buying advisable for quick profits.
One contract Ex. P-42: P.W. 2 ordered 100 bales cotton Jarilla for August 1958 at Rs. 654/- per candy.
Evidence of prosecution witnesses in Tamil or English; appellant knew neither; represented by advocates who knew both.
Six items of alleged cheating combined in one charge; lower courts found part of one transaction.

legal_issues.text: Whether case of cheating under s. 420 IPC made out against appellant.
Whether forward contracts were wagering contracts outside purview of Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952, and s. 15 not attracted.
Whether breach of s. 15 Act, or orders placed through member of recognised association.
Whether breach of s. 361 CrPC due to evidence not interpreted to appellant.
Whether conviction illegal due to combining six items of cheating in one charge.

petitioner_arguments.text: On admitted/proved facts no case of cheating under s. 420 IPC; no false representation or inducement.
Forward contract was wagering contract outside purview of Act; s. 2(c) to be literally construed for contracts intending actual delivery.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Forward Contracts Regulation Act s. 2(c), s. 15

petitioner_arguments.text: No breach of s. 15 as appellant placed orders through member of recognised association; acting as agent of P.W. 2.
Breach of s. 361 CrPC as evidence in Tamil/English not understood by appellant, vitiating trial.
Six items of cheating combined in one charge, making conviction illegal.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant induced P.W. 2 by fraudulent representation to part with Rs. 12,000/- though not entitled to conduct forward business.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: IPC s. 420; Forward Contracts Regulation Act s. 21(d),(e)

court_reasoning.text: Appellant made false representation in Ex. P-34(a) that he could do forward business per pucca adatia and associations' usage, knowing he had no right as non-member; inferred from circumstances; P.W. 2 would not have parted with money but for inducement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: False pretence may be inferred; concealed non-membership.

court_reasoning.text: Forward contracts include speculative ones per scheme/purpose of Act to regulate/eliminate unhealthy speculation; s. 2(c) not literal; Heydon's rule applies considering history/mischief.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ex. P-42 falls within forward contract definition.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence appellant placed orders through member; even if so, as pucca adatia acted as principal, not agent; no privity between P.W. 2 and association member.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pucca adatia substitutes own goods, acts principal to principal.

court_reasoning.text: Violation of s. 361 CrPC, if any, mere irregularity; no prejudice as no objection raised, represented by advocates knowing languages; s. 537 CrPC cures.
Six items part of one transaction; single charge permissible under s. 239 CrPC.

holdings.text: Case of cheating under s. 420 IPC made out.
Forward contracts, including speculative, within Act; provisions apply.
Breach of s. 15 and s. 21(d),(e) Act by non-member conducting business.
No vitiation of trial for s. 361 CrPC irregularity.
Single charge valid under s. 239 CrPC.

precedents_cited.relevance: Rule of interpretation: construe statute to suppress mischief, advance remedy.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bengal Immunity Company Limited v. State of Bihar
Bhagwandas A. Tarachand v. Kanji Deoji
precedents_cited.relevance: Pucca adatia not agent, acts as principal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhagwandas Parasram v. Burjorji Ruttonji Bomanji

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Cheating by inducement with false representation.

statutes_cited.name: Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates forward contracts; prohibits by non-members; penalties for false representation, canvassing.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Joinder of charges; interpretation of evidence; curing irregularities.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court affirmed Madras High Court judgment dismissing revision; upheld convictions and sentences under s. 420 IPC and s. 21(d),(e) Forward Contracts Regulation Act by District Magistrate, affirmed by Sessions Judge.

key_quotes.text: "It is not necessary that a false pretence should be made in express words by the appellant. It may be inferred from all the circumstances including the conduct of the appellant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes cheating via inferred false representation.

key_quotes.text: "If the expression 'forward contracts' in s. 2(c) is not so construed as to include speculative contracts which ostensibly are for delivery of goods the provisions of the Act would be rendered nugatory."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets scope of forward contracts under Act.

key_quotes.text: "The pucca adatia has no authority to pledge the credit of the upcountry constituent to the Bombay merchant and there is no privity of contract as between the upcountry constituent and the Bombay merchant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines role of pucca adatia, breach of s. 15.
